awd_titl_txt: EPRI/WERF: Collaborative Research: Electrical percolation in flowable electrodes for energy-efficient water re-use applications
awd_abstract_narration:
PI Name:  Kelsey Hatzell/Marta Hatzell
Proposal Number: 1706956/1706290
 
There is a growing need to develop low cost and modular water reuse systems to promote optimal reclamation and treatment of discharged water from industrial, municipal, agricultural and energy generation sites. Targeting strategies that optimize water usage could significantly alleviate stresses at the core of the food-energy-water nexus. The development of new water deionization technologies which can be easily scaled to meet the decentralized demands is imperative for water sustainability. Capacitive deionization is a cost effective and low energy electrochemical approach for treating brackish water streams; however, there are fundamental limitations to this approach because the process is not continuous. In this project a novel flow-electrode-based architecture is examined as a means for both continuous and scalable deionization and energy recovery.  The researchers plan to collaborate with local organizations (Georgia Intern Fellowship for Teachers and Vanderbilt School for Science and Math) in order to design an experiential curriculum on brackish water treatment to increase water literacy in the Southeast. 

The objective of this project is to advance fundamental understanding of the design of flowable electrode architectures for ion removal processes. The PIs plan to study the concept of flow-electrode capacitive deionization (FCDI) for water treatment.  FCDI systems have three flow channels, two of which serve to transport suspended activated carbon particles, which remove or electroadsorb ions, and a center channel where the feedwater is directed.  To date, few studies have explored the fundamental mechanisms which promote efficient charge transfer and storage within flow electrodes. Specifically, understanding the influence of hydrodynamics within a flowable electrode and its effect on the formation and disruption or percolation networks can potentially increase material utilization and control electrochemical penetration depths. The PIs seek to define a new theoretical framework to describe charging and electron conduction processes at the particle-particle level in order to elucidate idealized operating conditions that promote energy efficient ion removal processes. The PIs will investigate the percolation network of carbon particles in a flow electrode using computational fluid mechanics, advanced in-situ characterization, and bench scale experimentation to obtain new fundamental and applied knowledge regarding this emerging deionization technology. Direct interrogation of the electrical, mechanical and microstructural properties of flowable electrode percolation networks will be obtained through advanced synchrotron-based techniques. The work has the potential to guide the design of a new process for water purification and may have broader relevance for other environmental technologies involving energy storage, energy conversion, and desalination.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This proposal examined energy efficient ways to conduct separations related to solar desalination. We have several notable outcomes in the NSF Public Access Repository which detail each scientific contribution. These outcomes include published journal articles, conference presentations and conference proceedings. The funding of this work has funded 1/2 of a Phd degree and will directly supported an under-represented graduate student in STEM.

 

The intellectual merit of this proposal intended to look at non-equilibrium transformations in biphasic granular materials used for separations and energy transfer. The former (separations) is achieved by flowing particles through an electric field. Ions present in a solution can be electro--adsorbed on the particles causing a separations process to occur. Most modern separations processes utilize either heat or pressure driven processes to cause the separation process. However, moving toward electrifying separations provide a realistic pathway toward coupling renewable energy systems with industrial separations. Industrial applications (e.g. chemical manufacturing) accounts for nearly 30% of all greenhouse gases and these applications are plagued by energy intensive separation processes. Thus, this proposal directly addressed this need for electrifying separations processes.

 

At the core of this proposal we have completed three primary objectives: (1) direct x-ray imaging of particle flow reactors, (2) energy systems analysis of solar-integration with desalination, and (3) high temperature reactor design for thermal energy storage using particle flow reactors. Ultimately, it is challenging to understand how energy (electron, thermal, etc.) flows between particles in a suspension electrode or granular media. This is because the ?structure? or arrangement of particles changes with time and thus can result in an ensemble of different energy pathways. Ex situ or benchtop experiments can examine macro-scale properties but are not effective in tracking local interactions that occur when particles come into contact. With this grant we looked at using a technique known as synchrotron x-ray tomography to image particle flow electrodes/suspension media. Images can be reconstructed into three dimensional renderings and explored computationally. These techniques allows a pathway to post-mortem analysis and measurement of material properties inaccessible using traditional techniques.

 

In terms of broader impacts, this proposal seeks to examine pathways to decarbonize energy and water systems using novel low cost particle material systems for thermal energy storage and desalination. The work directly funded the training of an under-represented candidate in STEM.

 

Hatzell has participated and led numerous educational outreach events during the course of this proposal. Most notably, Hatzell led a demo during the 2018 and 2019 Maker day at Vanderbilt University. This event brings community members to Vanderbilt to participate on hands on activities related to science and engineering. Hatzell's group focused on demo-ing electrolysis ang green hydrogen production. The event draws over 500 people each year. In addition, Hatzell has led several demo's for middle school student during summer camps held during the summer through the Vanderbilt Insitute of Nanoscience and Engineering. Lastly, over the course of this grant Hatzell has mentored numerous undergraduate research experiences. Hatzell mentored over 20 students (5 URM, and 15 Women). 

 

Examples of papers reported on this grant are listed below (not complete but representative):

[1] Zhang, Jiankai, Kelsey B. Hatzell, and Marta C. Hatzell. "A combined heat-and power-driven membrane capacitive deionization system." Environmental Science & Technology Letters 4.11 (2017): 470-474.

[2] Zheng, Yanjie, and Kelsey B. Hatzell. "Technoeconomic analysis of solar thermal desalination." Desalination 474 (2020): 114168.

[3] Dixit, Marm B., et al. "Mapping charge percolation in flowable electrodes used in capacitive deionization." ACS Materials Letters 1.1 (2019): 71-76.

[4] Zaman, W., Matsumoto, R. A., Thompson, M. W., Liu, Y. H., Bootwala, Y., Dixit, M. B., ... & Hatzell, K. B. (2021). In situ investigation of water on MXene interfaces. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 118(49).

[5] Moreno, Daniel, Yousuf Bootwala, Wan-Yu Tsai, Qiang Gao, Fengyu Shen, Nina Balke, Kelsey B. Hatzell, and Marta C. Hatzell. "In situ electrochemical dilatometry of phosphate anion electrosorption." Environmental Science & Technology Letters 5, no. 12 (2018): 745-749

[6] Zheng, Y., Gonzalez, R. C., Hatzell, M. C., & Hatzell, K. B. (2021). Concentrating solar thermal desalination: Performance limitation analysis and possible pathways for improvement. Applied Thermal Engineering, 184, 116292

 


Last Modified: 12/14/2021
Modified by: Kelsey B Hatzell
